Type.Name: InterpType

TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi sealed InterpType extends System.Enum

Type.ThreadSafetyStatement: Gtk# is thread aware, but not thread safe; See the Gtk# Thread Programming for details.

Docs.remarks: Bilinear is the best balance in most cases. Nearest provides faster (and low quality) scaling, while Hyper is slow but high-quality.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype Gdk.InterpType Bilinear = int32(2)

Docs.summary: Best quality/speed balance; use this mode by default. Bilinear interpolation. For enlargement, it is equivalent to point-sampling the ideal bilinear-interpolated image. For reduction, it is equivalent to laying down small tiles and integrating over the coverage area.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype Gdk.InterpType Hyper = int32(3)

Docs.summary: This is the slowest and highest quality reconstruction function. It is derived from the hyperbolic filters in Wolberg's "Digital Image Warping", and is formally defined as the hyperbolic-filter sampling the ideal hyperbolic-filter interpolated image (the filter is designed to be idempotent for 1:1 pixel mapping).

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype Gdk.InterpType Nearest = int32(0)

Docs.summary: Nearest neighbor sampling; this is the fastest and lowest quality mode. Quality is normally unacceptable when scaling down, but may be OK when scaling up.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype Gdk.InterpType Tiles = int32(1)

Docs.summary: This is an accurate simulation of the PostScript image operator without any interpolation enabled. Each pixel is rendered as a tiny parallelogram of solid color, the edges of which are implemented with antialiasing. It resembles nearest neighbor for enlargement, and bilinear for reduction.
